titleStmt.title: CW 122
titleStmt.author: Carmichael, Alexander Archibald (1832‐1912)
titleStmt.sponsor: Edinburgh University Library and the Department of Scottish and Celtic Studies

interpretation.p: All digital surrogates of the original source are linked with the markup textfile.
All Gaelic (and some English) texts have an English summary, keywords, and, where applicable, a taxonomic reference.
For some Gaelic (and English) texts a bibliographic reference(s) will be provided to printed texts.

correction.p: Errors from the original source transcription have been kept to a minimum by employing a double re‐keying method when typed out. In addition, all re‐keyed texts have been proof‐read by the text editors.

A guiding principle of the Alexander Carmichael notebooks markup procedure is to approximate the original document as closely as possible, so that the character of Carmichael's transcriptions is preserved along with its content. XML (eXtensible Markup Language), with its capacity to convey emendations such as deletions (crossed out) and supralinear additions and so forth, can digitally reproduce an authentic version which reflects the source documents.
Where authorial changes, e.g. substitution, have occurred in the text then this has been annotated.
All words have been retained as written in the source text even when there are apparent errors in either spelling or when there has been either an omission in punctuation or grammar.

In such cases missing words or letters have not been supplied. Quotation marks and other missing grammatical marks have not been supplied. Where there are gaps in the text usually because the word was inaudible (some background noise, perhaps) or where the transcriber could not make out what was being said in the act of transcription (perhaps the speaker was inarticulate or mumbling or for whatever reason) then these have been tagged, though not explained; where a word is now difficult, illegible or just unclear, then this has also been tagged.
All such changes have been annotated in accordance with TEI 5 procedures.

normalization.p: No normalization of the words such as changing the source text to conform with current Gaelic orthographic conventions has been undertaken. The texts are as given with only minor editorial changes. in order to preserve the integrity of the original texts.

quotation.p: All opening quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, apostrophes, periods, colons, etc. have been retained in the source text and have been encoded in accodance with ISO entity references, etc.
All double marks have been processed using straight quotation marks, that is, ". All single quotation marks have been rendered using apostrophe.

hyphenation.p: End‐of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.

segmentation.p: Folio numbers have been added in pencil at the top of each notebook page are retained using the pb (pagebreak) element together with the n attribute for the page number and the ed attribute to specify the edition.
When an tale‐text or song which, more often than not, fills more than one page, it is segmented with page break.

A reference system has been built up using the identifiers of the following text units: text, division, paragraph. Each nested division has an identifier which is built up by successively adding to the identifier of the text. Each paragraph has an identifier which adds yet another layer to the immediately superordinate identifier.

langUsage.language: Approximately 95% of the texts are Scottish Gaelic, 2.5% of the texts are in Irish Gaelic and the remainder being roughly divided between English and Scots.

change.item: Proof-read item and made corrections as well as updating the catalogue entries.

div.title: Coisrigeadh an Aodaich
div.p:
Dun.Duncan Cameron Police Officer
Edinbgh.Edinburgh 7th AugAugust 1886

(Cuimhne an fheidh = Croic an
fheidh. "Cridhe do chuimhne
air a comhdach le stailinn")

lg.l: Sia rann, seacseachd gu'n leth rann
Nar a ghoinnar fear an side
Nuair a theid e 'n cath no coragcomhrag dha
Biolair air a buan ro fo ro lic
'S air a toirt do mhnaimhnaoi gun fhi] bhios

Lurg} Cuimhne}an fheidh an ceann
an sgadan
San caol chalp a bhradain bhric
S a'adach so 's chan aoibh fhaoibh e
S cha chuid cleir no sagart e

div.p:
The web is made into a roll
All the women work at the
roll patting it and the ranrann
is said three times over –
Then at the end the roll is
tossed end over and say
A aadh aodach seo &c
chan fhaoibh e.

Then turn it back and
say S cha chuid cleir
no sagart e.

Duncan Cameron Police-
man saw lump of peat
as large as houses on the
shore landed by the sea full
thick bark 1½ thick nuts
seed like lintseed = bog myrtle
seed the Knots of the wood
above remaining. Cameron dug
for lugachan and under the
sand found peat moss full
of seeds Dugald Macdugald
dug his peats there for several
years some feet in depth.
BhileBaile Pheatrais = full of round
molags. Plants like iris then
pressed west end of BBaile Pheatrais
near Ceann a Bhaigh

Eilean Druidhneach = Iona
The Isle of Sculptures

Maranach = wool of sheep dying of braxy
&c &c

Port nan lunn Bail iocrachiochdrach
Maoinish (Lunn = waves) The
foam Great accumullaccumulation of foam
here – flying like sea gulls.

Innis Draoineach, Eilean nan DraDraoineach
Iona. Draoineach in Skye
Innis Draoineach Droineach
on Lochawe is the isle of
the sculptors – Sculpturing

AiriAiridh-mùseig DunDuncan Cameron
cut with spade the cos of a nes
neas under the big stone
nothing but fionndach fhail
(mole) agus Seach ian
This was a big roomy place as
big as a big basket. He
saw nothing & he left. He
went a mile when he heard
Ness hissing at his heel and look
ing round he saw the neas.
She fled into a dyke a seideil
& hisghissing. As he went on the neas
kept up going into the dyke divgdiving
in & out and the kepg.keeping up with
him he pelting her with stones.

He came to the house of Angus
Carmichael at Bailiocrach
& was telling this to Eon Carm.Carmichael
son of Angus. DatDaughter of Isebal
Angus Isebal went to the door
& there the neas was standing
in the door. Dun.Duncan Cameron
& Eon Carmichael rushed
to the door then to trample
the neas but it eluded them
& eventually escaped into a
dyke – no more seen –

Eon Carmichael said. I will
not stop you lest she shdshould
cup cut y my throat instinstead of
yours but they went –

Myles Fletcher frfrom GlenorchyGlenorchy
Cen Laggan Ulva he found
the coascos of the neas & he came
to the airiairidh the isein of the neas.

The neas came & put two or
three buicein into a measair
bhan on a bench = Send him
the isean said her mother –
he saw & after a while the neas
even scraped of davuits into
this measair bhainne.

John Maclean Saor ToberyTobermory
FrFrom Sorne was in his barn
was in his barn when he saw
a neas among the daviots
& thatch above him. He ran
in and got a teth-thiallach
(spit) and progged the neas
When ever it appappeared – That night
his best calf was dead
This the man told me.

Eon Carmichael was hiring
a contract in Tom a chrochadair Cill a choain
at
Ardnamurchan. The
chickens were disappingdiasappearing. A
screech of a was heard early
in sumsummer morngmorning & the girl
datdaughter of house ran to a cliabh
down in end of house & she
found a neas killgkilling the chickchicken
The girl cautcaught chicken an in
one hand & neas in the other
& brotbrought them up. Eon CarmCarmichael
took hold of neas with tongs
& killed it but not before
it killed chickchicken – never relaxing
its hold

The stink of the neas is
horrible – poisonous in extreme
no living creatcreature can stand it

Airi.Airidh-miseig = Miseig, young
goat before it kids

lg.l: Gun fhios ciod a ni mi

Gun a mart min a chuir
las an lar

div.p:
The neas hates the smell of
burning. So the people burn
the tail & cas of the calf when
calved or burn dry old shoe
or leather. A calf

Saw two maideanmaighdeann bhuana
in house of DonDonald Maclean Tober-
mory. Try who can harvharvest it. This
again is given to horses in first
sgriob turadh.

Seamalach = Heifer whose calf
was killed – no calf of heifer kept
in olden times. In caraideach
adh = The calf of one cow heifheifer is
killed & tail cut off & tied to clook
placed on the livgliving calf & he sukdsuckled
the two dams. This was caraid
eachadh
Stōdh = Stewing

lg.l:
Fear air muin eich bhain
dol gu gach taigh saigh

Da chois chapuill chaoil
an cro?
Shaoil uthu gur an n chon
Theid do chioch leis na taodaibh
Dar chois chapaill chaoil an cro?
Suai aidh an eala ban fhaoil

Tri aoisean caorach dui crithe cridh
anaich a sior mhuilt

div.p:
Beann = Horn Caor bean
ach

Fhuair mi deoch a lamh ririgh
Alba a cup airgid agus oir
Fhuair mi rud nach saoil
ri fhaotfhaotainn Da chois?

An aghaiaghaidh a cluig
Thighin an fheadag air a bhiodaig
S theap mi manadh
Deoch ceol air an tapadh
Suraig nach ainireamh
Air a mhiapadh.

Bha mi 7 seacseachd sabhauil
Air urlar cruaicruaidh foghair
S gad gheo'aingheobhainn am bas
anns a bhrochain
S chan fheighfhaigh deoch bhon
chuadan

"T fhalt agagus t fhiona D. haoinDiahaoine
T ionga mhaol D sathurnDiasathurna"

lg.l: "Air a bhiolain san an t siutha
Air a ghuthan an ni an t eun
SanSann a choilll ud thall fo dhuil
Cha d idird fhidir duine mo sgeul

div.p: DunDuncan Cameron, Lochaline,

Hug o hug o the ffullgfulling song
Six women working like furies One women
sang the rest sang chorus. No song
must be sang twice or else it takes
back the cloth

Cailin og is stiurami
They lift the cloth bodily off the cliath
Work like furies at fulling
Failil o ro hill oro

div.p: See All – an t suain

Aithean guail 6 or 7 of got in
Bail iocrachiochdrach n Mull. Ealaghu
Eǎlaghual = Wood coal
esplyespecially of the willow

Lobster got on high sea
level in Port Mor in
rock ar in fissure of
red gairial.

In AiriAiridh nan Cailleach
had a cladh Brĭit number
of cut stones & cross put into
dykes by the farmers who had
the place. Also Cille chriosd
had stones with holes throthrough them
Cladh mhoire down below
Castle of Calgarry. Still burying
there – beautiful place.

Is toigh leis gach uidh a
shamhuil

Remains of houses under low
water below Taighean &c.

An Cuillionn Rumach
the Cuillionn of Rum. An
Cuillion
Sgitheanach = the Cullion of Skye

x Cladh Muluag Treisnish
3 ftfeet standing cross cut on stone
small arms of cross – worn

Got Celt from Mor Dhughallach
Na h-Abhan auan Treisnish
Mull Sunday 15 Augt.August 1886.
also crystal cube – crystal cube

Tobar Chaluimchille at the pen
coming out of rock – excltexcellent water

See "Legend of Montrose Scott
For Children of the Mist" – Aoidh
Clann Aoidh"

A man who reprobated having
any papanich thing in the cladh
carried down the cross & threw it into
the sea at
His cattle & sheep died &c & so he went
and fished it up & replaced the cross

Time of Eigg & Bloody Bay
was time when wars at Carn
Cairnaburg. Macleod Dun
veagain & Lochbuy takes
out the fort (or Duart)
When the castellan saw he
was betrayed he cariedcarried the trea
sure up & threw it in the well
where it is buried. closed
up now simply a hollow
The treasure brotbrought from
Iona

Calgarry which all the rocks to be
& classic Swanibol

Cladh Bhriit at Airin
cross then standing in socket
1½ ffeet high. broken now.
Cladh Chraigeig –at in
Aoinidh Chraigeig

Macquarie of Ulva (Col) had
toddy ladle. He was in war
of Egypt had ladle then? Had
a brothbrother a general who had
Glenforsa. Capt Macquarie
Salen is son of Col doMacquarrie.

Cairnaburg mor DoCairnaburg beag. Flata
Lunga B Am baca mor Doam baca beag
Sgeir an Eireannaich nearest
Fladda. Sgeir nan Caisteal (grass
& flock on them)

At Cragaig a sep serpent stung and
killed a fine man – black spot above
teeth serpents 2½ ft.feet – threetwo thirds
red. black & speckled. • Sting on
of mane. Dip dogs in sea & give them
milk.

Eiseig a farm on slope of hill –
C Cladh na Faoilinn. Faoileann
a low terrace near the sea.

SlocSlochd Brăn in Cairnaborg mor
Forts in both.

Dun chruit in Lunga – a
man fell down in search of gull eggs

In Lunga large ship full of cotton
broken & all lost then.

The lobster & cruban cast the
shell in the Iuchar

Calf of 2 heads tails & 8 feet
at Calgary with Capt Macasg
ail – wldwould not allow them
to kill it so was buried alive
the raoic he gave the glen
around answered & fright
ened the people

div.title: "DonlDomhnull a ghleidhidh"
div.p:
Never put off his cota mor
for 7 years except one day
he threw it off
an Aigh said he. They
He & found it so – He
was a fiosaiche

Du-sithDubh-sith beag MacIlle-
She'anaichMacille-Sheathanaich put egg on
head of his boy & broke it then
killkilled the creatcreature before all but
three

Uiridh = Sgliff = Terrace as
Uiridh Ailean nan Sop in Cairn
Burg mor. When he jumped
down when chased. Bail chlarsair
had clarsair had this for his
clarsaireacclarsaireachd.

Eas-Fors (force?) march betbetween Laggan
& Cillabhrianan
{Cardag Càlag = Dooker LessLesser Guillemote

DDonald Maclean of Coll & Lochbuy
& Saxon – shooting on Sunday
across the hill. roasted grouse
– Coll threw this and ththat taken
(On Mull side of Ulva sound
columns like Staffa) All in
boat capsigcapsizing & settled. Loch
buy man scrambled to the mast
Lochbuy asked him to let
him out. fad bha uthu os rud
mo chionn san t saoghal
cha bhi uthu os m chionn
san a shaoghal thall

RiRigh Acharainich (Eoin Campbell
got the man when a lad from
his pride)

Dun-virimil when Clark
of Ulva buryburied took up large stone
fine shot high

Ulva wont to swim to Innis
to see a girl – met bull on rocrock
in mid channel took rear
offof bull to threw him again

in girl him
sent to put round cliar
Why said she sent ye Mac
Cuaire mor to me when
she ran back. FathFather you are
perhaps you MaqMaquarie
mor yet.

Innis Kenneth Tuesday 17th AugAugust 861886
Conglomerate rock.

A slender slate cross inside tung
of Col Macdonald – very pretty
leaning against wall.

Stone H M 1676 Stones of
native stone of conglomConglomerate Cladh
mor extension – FarmFarmer ploughploughed
up cut skulls – LachLachlan Campbell
now.

AnothAnother stone 1778 – FounFound
sculpsculptered stone in native rock but
beautifully sculpdsculptured

Sir Allan s hands could be
under his gartan stands – long hose
Effigy in full HighHighland dress target
and clogaid – On Iona stone in
tunga Sir Allan On Two Iona stone
inside church 12 or 13 slates in
length & 6 abtabout 10 or 12 ftfeet wall an
L Two lancet under on EEast end and close
togethtogether. Supports on both winswindows
of bow (EEast) and to keep up build
ing walls. Tung of Sir Allan
on ssouth side of east corner.
Sir Allan of Brolas family.
Macinnon of Gribun of east
of church – daoine laidir.

good well last of this a little
Mureachan pl.place of uridh
Maceir = Mac sgeoil = Free let free

Coillimore house Tuesday
Night 17 AugAugust 1886.
Dr. Aisley marmarried to niece
of Mrs Colin Maciver here
says he dissected a royal
subject in Edinburgh UnityUniversity
when assitassistant to Professor
GodsirGoodsir Dr GodsirGoodsir came
round and said you will
oblige me much by dis
contgdiscountinuing. your often on that
subject. Young subject
was Prince SobeskiSobieski
of Poland wounded in the
tibia at the battle of
He found his way as refugee
to Scotland became
lived in the Cannon
gate suppsupported by a fam 2 or 3 friends
of whom I am I happily
was one. He got ill went
into the infirmary where he
died three days ago unknown
to us. You will find a
bullet wounds in
I wish to bury him &c
All the wounds were as described

Left Ceannloch Inn at 10 am
19 AugAugust 861886. In company with Mr
from London who
had been geologising in Mull
for some time. The view from
the mountain track down Loch
Scridein is very fine & so is the
view from the pass looking down
the glen to Lochbā. On the
higher part of the pass is a
big cairn evidently the re-
sult of funerals. 1088 ffeet high I
saw very yellow frog near summit
of pass. View down the glen
to Lochba glorious in the bright
sun after the rain the grass spark
ling in the sun and every rill
laughed gach caochain
sa ghleann ri gaire

lg.l: Si ghalghalla uainuaine a sharaich mi

div.p:
Went into uaiuamh du chraichraidh
& under standing Creagan
he was heard when the galgalla
uainuaine attacked him.
(Bachuill)

Cillantsuidhe Achadhun
Monday 23 AugAugust 1886 –
A circle under rushes & ferns
especially iris. 37 yards x 37
Ard from sea by a small ridge
in a field low lying between
ridges.

Vitrified fort at RahoyRahoy Torr-
noieg. Dunfionn a for-
ear lived there.

div.title: Run-rig at Hosta
div.p:
The Hosta tentstenants divdivided the land at tiny
intervals from NovNovember to May. The area
did on any part occasion is regu
lated to some extent by the quantity
of seaweed at their disposal They
div.divided a field into a sets of rigs each
set consisting of five of equal
area – there being five tenants
in the place. Each tenant
takes possession of the rig in
the first set falling his lot and
keeps it as long as he continuous crop-
ping goes on – a period of from
two to three years according to the
nature of the soil. If the rigs in the
first set very with respect to quality
in terms of the arrangement or
the agreement the man to
whose lot the worst rig in the
first set has fallen get his choice
of the rigs in the second sets.
Perhaps this privilege is conceded
to two or three each in his turn,
getting his choice in the second
sets so that the man to whose lot
the best rig fell in the first set
must be contend to accept
the worst rig in the second set
and so on of the other tenants
according to prearranged
prescribed rules – This aims
at balancing pasture to all as
nearly as possible – If the field
is uniform as to quality lots
determines which rig it to be own
ed by each tenant. But if the field
is irregular in quality the order
of possessorship in the first set
is reversed in the second set
Thus the man who gets the first
rig in the first set gets not by
lot by but by fixed rule the fifth
rig in the second set. This is the
system at Caolas Paible and
Heisgeir as well as Hosta.
From Mr Angus Macquarrie
Schoolmaster Taighearry N.North Uist
20 Oct.October 1884

Dry in spring tide – stepping
stone – like eel. Ducks of long
bills nesting in this isle

Ian Lom born in Barra
glas Glenlonan. A
Mac Calman his mother
Campbell his father. His
called Mac a ghlasaraich
Gleann a ghlas ruith
from the Glas river
in Kill michael

he spoke

brog

list.item: Caigeal = Shallow neck with narrow opening

lg.l: ChitherChithear fiadh a snamh a nan speur
Mun faighear fairear agamsa mar cheile
Chroch an te sin i feinfhein ri craoibh
Gun d fhuair lucluchd eon deige
A feil ga riasladh aig coin nan speur

div.p:
A girl who hanged herself on being
jilted

LaLatha fheil Moire na Feill PeadPeadair
LaLatha s mu thig no thainig
25 March. Annunciation Day
When it falls on Good Friday
calamitous for Europe – war
pestilence &c.

Seacaid mhaide agus peitein
iarrain a bhibhith na mu'n
cuach air an duine fad lalatha agus
bliadhna air thug an t eurball
as an lair agam
Eala-ghal (Elgol) place nearin Skye

After Father Macgregor IocarIochdar
had been reading the bible and ex-
pounding its doctrines to his
catechist. Donald Macintire
Domhul Macdhomhnuil ic Thear
laich – he said – Thugamaid a nis
treis air Oisein and taking over
Macpherson's Gaelic Ossian –
M' anamsa Dhia s e b annsa
leinn said the catechist!

Tha easan cocho crosda ri bod-
achan sathaidh!
Is measa am fear beag nam
Fraigach!
An lalatha sloinne(?)

When Campbell of Islay had
Pool House at Poolewe John FFrancis
Campbell then just of age was
passing along the road when
people were carrying sea weed on
their back to the roadside. A hand
some young girl gazing at
the young man passing said
A Dhia nach robh thu posd agam!
Nan robh cha bhiodh tu fon chliabh
agam said he in as good Gaelic
as her own. The poor girl was
so taken aback at the unexpected
Gaelic that she threw the crelcreel
from her ran home as fast
as her legs could carry her
nor would she move out of
the house or go near the place
while the Campbells came there.

"Cha ghluaiseadh brog no
bruithinn gu feamanadh tuilidhtuillidh
i fad agus bha Tighearna Ile sin."

ionndrain

sala
Na fearaibh a dh-fhalbh an de

maireach

div.title: Wolves
div.p:
Hospital at Flixton, Folkston Yorkshire
to preserve travellers from being devoured
by the wolves and other wild beasts of
the district – in the time of Athel-
stane. See LeproseyLeprosy.
